Uni-axial loading & Deformation

A bar is loaded by two forces and we are interested in the relative motion between the points of application of forces.

 

The three rods are made of the same material.

 

The maximum elongation is small (less than 0.1% of the original length)
We plot load versus deflection for the three bars. For a linear material, the load deflection behaviour is linear.
For a non-linear material, the load deflection behaviour is non-linear
We define :

Axial Stress = Load /  Area

σ = P/A

Axial Strain = Change in length per unit length

ε = δ / L

In the linear Elastic range

σ = E ε

E is called Modulus of elastic (or Young's modulus)

Stress-strain diagrams are obtained using a tensile test. Stress-Strain diagrams are independent of specimen size.
Tensile test

In a typical tensile test, a cylindrical test specimen is used.

The ends are moved apart by a testing machine which indicates the load required at each stage.

 

The tension specimen is held in the jaws of a testing machine. Sometimes an extensometer is used to measure the change in length

 

The longitudinal and lateral strain are recorded as the test proceeds.

 

 

Typical stress strain curve
Typical contraction of a mild steel specimen near the breaking point

Uni-axial loading & Deformation

Material

E (GPa)

1 Pa = 1 N/m2

1 GPa = 109N/m2

Steel & Iron

194-205

Aluminum

 69

Brass

 103

Cast Iron

 69-138
Wood 10

Soft Rubber

.0014-.005

 

For many engineering materials, the modulus of elasticity values in compression and tension are nearly equal.

Thus the relation :δ= PL/AE is valid in both tension and  compression and EA/L can be thought of as the stiffness of the bar in tension & compression.

Let us do some order of magnitude calculations.

In most engineering structures, the deformations are of the order of 0.1% or less.

Consider a brass rod 1 m length, 10 mm dia.  Ebrass is equal to 103GPA

Assume that a load of 8100 N is applied on the brass rod.

Area of brass rod = π d2 / 4

Or Area=π 102 / 4 mm2 = =7.85*10-5 m2

Extension of brass rod  = PL/AE =8100*1/ (7.85*10-5 *103*109)

Extension = .001 m = 1 mm

Extension / Length = .001 (0.1 percent)

When a solid is subjected to axial tension, the solid contracts laterally.

 

Poisson’s ratio (ν )is defined as:

 

ν = -(lateral strain divided by axial strain)
